title: Territory Parks and Wildlife provide kids with opportunities to learn and explore - Travelandtourworld.comTravelandtourworld.com
text:
Territory Parks and Wildlife provide kids with opportunities to learn and explore Published on : Monday, September 14, 2015
Tonight the Minister for Parks and Wildlife, Bess Price, welcomed the Territory’s large junior ranger community into Parliament House.
The Junior Ranger Program provides kids with a focus to discover, explore, learn and contribute to the natural and cultural environment.
“Establishing a young and fun ranger network in 1991 has provided a valuable opportunity for generations of kids aged 9-12 to express their passion for parks and the environment,” Minister Price said.
“Tonight many junior rangers and their families gave various perspectives on how we can protect our natural environment, how to improve services, and what the next generation of parks enthusiasts want in the great outdoors.
“I was impressed with the junior rangers understanding on conserving nature and culture in the Northern Territory, and their enthusiasm was infectious and there for all to see tonight.
“Our parks are in great hands judging by an impressive turn out tonight, and participants in the program are learning new skills, raising environmental awareness, connecting with the local environment and inspiring us all to protect and enjoy the Northern Territory’s parks.”
Hundreds of Territory kids have participated in the free Junior Ranger Program and is aimed at boys and girls aged 9-12. Kids learn about the great outdoors, interesting plants and native animals that are ever present in our amazing environment.
Junior Rangers learn through a special program by visiting parks, picking-up animals, meeting with park Rangers and gaining information from scientists.
Community Engagement Rangers deliver the program with the assistance of staff in Parks and Wildlife. Junior Ranger Programs exist and are growing in Darwin, Katherine and Alice Springs.
“Tonight I put a call out to Territory kids to get involved and participate in the junior ranger program and you could find yourself investigating water bugs, spotlighting nocturnal wildlife, spying on birds with binoculars and exploring Indigenous culture,” Mrs Price said.
“The insight gained into Parks and Wildlife could inspire these junior rangers to a career in wildlife/land care and if they move into other career areas they will have obtained knowledge and skills from their time as rangers that will last a lifetime.”
